title: Former Liverpool defender Steven Caulker recalls tragic car accident that killed teammate
text:

Former Liverpool defender Steven Caulker has opened up on the heartbreaking accident which killed teammate Josef Sural earlier this year.

Caulker signed for Turkish side Alanyaspor back in January, and was presented to the media on the same day as fellow new addition Sural - who had come from Czech side Sparta Prague.

The pair struck up an instant friendship, rooming together on club duties and helping each other adjust to their new life in Turkey.

But Sural's life was tragically taken when he was killed in a car accident - which Caulker was also a passenger in - following their sides draw with Kayserispor in April.

“Even now, none of it makes any sense,” Caulker told the Athletic's Dominic Fifield. “It was so cruel."

(Image: Josef Sural /Instagram)

After a scheduled flight taking the team back from Kayseri was delayed by eight hours, several players decided to hire a minibus for the journey and set off that evening.

Caulker and Sural, 28, were among those on the bus to make the 370-mile trip back, along with ex-Newcastle striker Papiss Cisse, and were being driven by two chauffeurs when the bus careered off the road just two miles from home.

The club president Hasan Cavusoglu has since claimed that both drivers had fallen asleep at the wheel, with the time at 2am following the six-hour trip.

“He swerved into the ditch and we maybe travelled down that for about 50 metres," Caulker said. "The sliding door was ripped open. We all took cover, screaming, covering our heads with our hands. When it all stopped, we scrambled out and were just checking each other, making sure we were OK.

(Image: Getty Images)

“There were a few minor head injuries, Isaac [Sackey] had broken his hand… everything was smashed to pieces. Windows, doors, everything. The bus was a mess. We were all in shock but, because I’d somehow come away untouched, I was just trying to calm people down. It was only after about two or three minutes that we realised Josef wasn’t there.

“That’s when we heard people screaming further back down the road from where we’d come, and someone turned to me and said: ‘That’s him. That’s Sural.’ I just sprinted down to where they were, and saw him. He was lying there on the floor, breathing heavily… I sat there with him, talking to him, speaking with my friend, trying to keep him awake until the ambulance eventually came. It was all I could do.”

(Image: Josef Sural /Instagram)

Sural and his teammates on board were taken to Alanya Anadolu private hospital.

Except for Caulker, who went to tell Sural's wife of the incident at their house, before heading to the hospital with her and their four-year old daughter.

After playing with Sural's daughter at the hospital for some time, Caulker and the other players were all sent home, with their teammate expected to make a full recovery, but at 7am Caulker received the message that his friend had passed away.

(Image: Getty Images)

He then had to attend Sural's funeral on the same day, in keeping with local traditions, as the Alanyaspor players were still struggling to come to terms with what had happened.

They donned black shirts and laid roses on Sural's coffin, with the club providing support to the late forward's family ever since.

Caulker added: "His memory lives on. His picture is up at the training ground, in the stadium. He is still one of us. He’ll never be forgotten.”
description: The England international moved to Turkey in January but was immediately hit by tragic events just months later
